questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequent presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abdominal mass

 

The most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor is as an abdominal mass.

 

Abdominal mass is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are characterized by the development of firm, palpable masses in the abdominal wall or other abdominal structures. This is the hallmark sign of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal pain: While abdominal pain can be a symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors, it is not the most frequent presentation. These tumors often manifest as painless masses in the abdominal area.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is generally not a primary symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are primarily associated with the formation of masses rather than systemic symptoms like fever.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse: Rectal prolapse is not a common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An abdominal desmoid tumor is a tumor that arises from fibro-aponeurotic tissue in the musculoaponeurotic structures of the abdominal wall, especially below the level of the umbilicus.

 

Desmoid tumors are frequently seen to be associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) syndrome.

 

It commonly presents as a slow-growing mass and tends to infiltrate muscle in the immediate area. Eventually, it can undergo a myxomatous change and then shows an increase in size more rapidly.

 

The investigation of choice for desmoid tumor is MRI. Biopsy with immunohistochemistry can help in establishing the diagnosis. The tumors typically stain positive for

 

  • 3-catenin
  • Actin and
  • Vimentin.

 

It stains negative for cytokeratin and S-100.

 

  • Treatment includes wide excision with a margin clearance of 2.5cm to avoid recurrence. It is a completely unencapsulated fibroma and is hard to cut. The defect then requires repair using mesh to prevent hernia in the future.
  • Radiotherapy alone is an acceptable treatment option for patients with unresectable desmoid tumors
  • Prognosis is good, with no metastasis or sarcomatous change. Although they lack metastatic potential, they can be multifocal as well as locally aggressive and invasive, with a high propensity for recurrence.

questions.text: Which is the most common Osteoporotic fracture site?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebral fracture

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • The fractures that are most common (in decreasing order) are vertebral fracture > hip (neck femur) > lower end radius.
  • Most of the vertebral fractures are asymptomatic and are identified incidentally during radiograph for other purpose.
  • Few of these present as backache of varying degree.
  • Up to 70 years of age, the order of fracture incidence is vertebral > Colle’s.
  • Overall and in > 70 years of age, it is vertebral > Hip > Colle’s.
  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), codfish appearance and pencilling of vertebrae.

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra (Biconcave vertebra)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intertrochanteric fracture: These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. These patients are also typically older than patients who suffer femoral neck fractures. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism. The femur is the second most common site of fracture in the osteoporotic patients.

 

Option C. Femoral shaft fracture: Femoral shaft fractures can result from high or low energy mechanisms. The most common causes include automobile accidents, falls from heights, ground-level falls in individuals with osteoporosis, and gunshots. About 75% fractures are caused by high energy mechanisms. Other less common causes are atypical fractures from bisphosphonate use, pathologic fractures through a bone lesion, insufficiency fractures from osteoporosis, and stress fractures from overuse in athletes.

 

Option D. Subtrochanteric fracture: Subtrochanteric fractures are mainly seen in 2 patient populations: spiral fractures in osteoporotic patients and atypical insufficiency fractures that happen after no to low-energy trauma (e.g., patients who use long-term bisphosphate therapy). But femur involvement is the second common site in osteoporosis for fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.

choices.text: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) - M7
Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue, night sweats, and painless lymph node swelling. She reports unintentional weight loss and occasional low-grade fevers. Physical examination reveals multiple, firm, non-tender lymph nodes in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions. Laboratory tests show mild anemia with normal white blood cell and platelet counts. Imaging reveals generalized lymphadenopathy without splenomegaly. A bone marrow aspiration is planned to evaluate for potential marrow involvement, but the clinician is concerned about the possibility of a dry tap. Which of the following conditions is least likely to result in a dry tap during a bone marrow aspiration?
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Follicular Lymphoma

 

Explanation:

 

A dry tap during bone marrow aspiration occurs when the aspiration needle fails to retrieve adequate marrow cells.

 

Follicular lymphoma, while it can involve the bone marrow, typically infiltrates in a less disruptive manner. It doesn't cause extensive fibrosis or significantly alter the marrow architecture, allowing for successful aspiration in most cases.

 

Causes of dry tap are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AML-M7 (Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia): Megakaryoblasts in this subtype often stimulate marrow fibrosis, leading to dry taps.

 

Option B. CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia): In advanced stages, CML can progress to a fibrotic phase, making aspiration difficult.

 

Option C. Myelofibrosis: This condition is characterized by extensive marrow fibrosis, making dry taps a hallmark feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of dry tap are:

  • Faulty technique
  • Metastatic carcinoma infiltration
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Myelofibrosis
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Acute leukemia
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • AML- M7

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.

  • Common intraocular foreign bodies:
    • Glass particles or metal chips.
  • Sites of lodgement: 
    • The anterior chamber
    • Lens
    • Posterior chamber
    • Vitreous humour
  • Consequences of lodgement: 
    • Cataract formation
    • Vitreous liquefaction
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Tears
    • Organic foreign bodies can cause infection.
    • Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis.
    • Copper ones can result in chalcosis.
  • An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein.
  • MRI is contraindicated in metallic intraocular foreign bodies.

 

Option C.

 

Ocular trauma can be of 2 types:

  1. Closed-globe injury: can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.
  2. Open-globe injury: includes globe rupture or laceration.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the constricted pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) After cataract

 

(SYNONYMS: POSTERIOR CAPSULAR OPACIFICATION/SECOND CATARACT)

 

  • Elschnig's pearls are a type of after cataract, a delayed complication of cataract surgery.
  • They are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles, along the posterior capsule of the lens.

 

Types of after cataract:

 

  • ﻿﻿Thin membranous after-cataract (thickened posterior capsule)
  • ﻿﻿Dense membranous after-cataract
  • ﻿﻿Soemmering ring: peripheral thick ring of opacity between 2 capsules.
  • ﻿Elschnig's pearls

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Irvine-Gass syndrome:

 

  • Postoperative cystoid macular edema classically described as vitreous touch syndrome.
  • Can occur upto 6 months post cataract surgery.
  • Resolves on its own.
  • Non resolving Irvine Gass syndrome is treated with topical NSAID eye drops, intra and periocular steroid injection and intravitreal Anti-VEGF injection.

 

Option C. Endophthalmitis:

 

  • Caused by an organism of low virulence (Propionibacterium acne or Staphylococcus epidermidis) becoming trapped within the capsular bag
  • Characterized by pain and redness
  • Delayed complication
  • Treatment is removal of entire IOL-Bag complex along with vitrectomy and secondary IOL implantation – either sclera fixation / iris claw IOL / Anterior chamber IOL.

 

Option D. Uveitis-glaucoma-hyphema syndrome:

 

  • Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema occurring simultaneously
  • Seen after anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation
  • Also seen when foldable hydrophilic IOL is implanted in ciliary sulcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior capsular opacification or after cataract is a common post-surgical complication following cataract surgery, characterized by the proliferation of lens epithelial cells leading to opacification of the posterior capsule. This can diminish vision and may require further treatment, typically a simple laser procedure called a YAG capsulotomy to restore clarity to the visual axis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anovulation

 

Explanation:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia. Menorrhagia refers to heavy menstrual bleeding that occurs in a regular cycle. In adolescents, anovulation, which is the failure of the ovary to release an oocyte during a menstrual cycle, frequently leads to heavy or prolonged bleeding due to the lack of a normal hormonal cycle that regulates the endometrial lining. Without the usual cyclical hormonal fluctuations, the endometrial lining may become excessively thick, leading to heavy bleeding when it sheds. This condition is typical in puberty due to the body's ongoing adjustment to hormonal regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, which can cause painful menstruation and potentially contribute to menorrhagia. However, it is less common than anovulation as the primary cause of menorrhagia in adolescents.

 

Option C. Malignancy: Malignancy is a rare cause of menorrhagia in puberty. While malignancy can lead to abnormal bleeding, it is not the most common cause in this age group.

 

Option D. Bleeding disorder: Bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease or hemophilia can cause menorrhagia but are less common compared to anovulation in adolescents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with spinal TB; he has a swelling in the left groin with limb attitude is in flexion. Identify what caused it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with Pott spine having persistent hip flexion with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle, marked A in the given coronal CT image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with spinal TB, a psoas abscess is a significant complication that can lead to symptoms such as groin swelling and changes in limb posture due to its location and the effect of the abscess on the surrounding structures, particularly the psoas muscle. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause flagellated pigmentation of skin? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bleomycin

 

Bleomycin is the chemotherapeutic drug that is known to cause flagellated hyperpigmentation in the skin. Another side effect of Bleomycin is pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Doxorubicin: This chemotherapeutic agent is known for causing cardiotoxicity and myelosuppression, but it does not typically cause flagellated pigmentation of the skin.

 

Option C. Vincristine: This drug is associated with neurotoxicity, particularly peripheral neuropathy, but it does not cause flagellated hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Minocycline: This antibiotic can cause skin pigmentation, but it is not typically flagellated. The pigmentation with minocycline tends to be more diffuse and can affect the skin, nails, and other tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleomycin is known to cause flagellated hyperpigmentation of the skin as a unique side effect. It can also cause pulmonary fibrosis, making it important to monitor patients for respiratory symptoms during treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Ca2+

 

  • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.

 

Option C. Glucose:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):

 

  • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers Pi, uses PLP (B6) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic liver disease is experiencing recurrent urinary tract infections. His healthcare team is considering various antibiotics, including fluoroquinolones, to treat the infection. Which of the following fluoroquinolones is not recommended for use in patients with liver disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pefloxacin

 

  • Pefloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that is primarily eliminated by the liver. In patients with liver disease, pefloxacin can accumulate in the body and cause hepatotoxicity. Therefore, it is not recommended for use in patients with liver disease or hepatic impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that is eliminated by both the liver and the kidneys. It can be used with caution in patients with liver disease, provided the dosage is adjusted according to hepatic function.

 

Option B. Levofloxacin: Levofloxacin is another fluoroquinolone that is eliminated by both the liver and kidneys. It is generally considered safe for use in patients with liver disease, with appropriate dose adjustments based on hepatic function.

 

Option D. Lomefloxacin: Lomefloxacin is also eliminated by both the liver and kidneys and can be used in patients with liver disease, provided that dosage adjustments are made.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones that are safe in renal failure, avoided in liver failure and not effective in UTI include:

 

  • P: Pefloxacin
  • M: Moxifloxacin
  • T: Trovafloxacin

choices.text: Congestive heart failure

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 58-year-old man with multiple lower limb fractures and lung contusion was brought to the hospital, where he later died. An autopsy lung biopsy revealed certain features. What is the most likely cause of his death? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Fat embolism

 

Explanation:

 

A traumatic accident that resulted in extensive fractures, particularly in the long bones of the lower limbs, which predisposes to fat embolism. This condition typically occurs when bone marrow fat is mobilized into the bloodstream following a fracture, blocking pulmonary vasculature. Histopathological findings from the lung biopsy likely included the presence of fat globules in pulmonary vessels, a hallmark of fat embolism syndrome (FES). This syndrome is a known complication of such injuries and aligns with the clinical context and autopsy findings.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Emphysema: This is a chronic condition leading to airspace enlargement and does not occur acutely due to trauma.
  • Option B. Congestive heart failure: While it can cause pulmonary edema, it is unlikely to acutely result from trauma unless there was a cardiac injury, which is not indicated in this scenario.
  • Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Typically involves a clot from the deep veins (thromboembolism), not fat from fractures, and would show different histopathological features.

 

Educational Objective: In patients with multiple fractures, especially of long bones, it is crucial to monitor for signs of fat embolism syndrome, characterized by respiratory distress, neurological symptoms, and a petechial rash.

questions.text: What is the causative agent for Hooch tragedy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Methanol

 

Hooch tragedy is due to the consumption of adulterated liquor containing methanol. Methanol is a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health issues including blindness, metabolic acidosis, and death when ingested.

 

Hooch

 

  • Definition: It is ethyl alcohol illegally adulterated with other harmful substances
  • Methanol as adulterant: A common harmful adulterant in hooch is methanol
  • Sources of methanol in Ethanol: There are two ways by which methanol gets added in the ethanol:
    • Added deliberately to ethanol due to its low price or
    • Produced during ethanol production (fermentation): Methanol can get naturally produced along with ethanol during the production of ethanol by fermentation. Usually it gets removed by distillation, but in local and illegal production, the distillation is of poor quality.
  • Hooch tragedy in India: In India, local alcohol is made illegally from cane sugar, is sold very cheap for a plastic pouch or glass. In Bihar and some other states, it has resulted in deaths of multiple people at different times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning usually occurs due to ingestion of substances like rodenticides or fireworks and is not associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning occurs from exposure to mercury or its compounds and is not linked to hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethanol: Ethanol is the intended product of alcoholic beverages. It is not the cause of hooch tragedies unless it is adulterated with toxic substances like methanol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hooch tragedies occur due to the consumption of illicitly brewed liquor contaminated with methanol, a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health effects including death.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

 

In the case described above, the neonate had unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, but had normal liver enzymes, PT/INR, and albumin levels, and no hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Crigler-Najjar type 2. The fact that bilirubin levels dropped after treatment with phenobarbital further supports this diagnosis.

 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

 

  • Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia- Physiologic (newborn), Crigler-Najjar, Gilbert syndrome, Hemolytic
  • Gilbert syndrome: Partial deficiency of uridine diphosphate glucuronyltransferase (UDPGT) caused by polymorphism. It is more common, affecting 5-10%. It occurs after puberty. It is not associated with chronic liver disease and no treatment is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotor syndrome: Rotor syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, not unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Like Rotor syndrome, Dubin-Johnson syndrome is also characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It presents with a dark liver on gross examination due to the accumulation of pigment, which is not consistent with the findings described.

 

Option D. Crigler-Najjar type 1: This condition is more severe than type 2 and typically presents with extremely high levels of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to a high risk of kernicterus. Patients with Crigler-Najjar type 1 do not respond to phenobarbital treatment, unlike the neonate described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with chronic liver disease is evaluated using the Child-Pugh score, which categorizes patients into classes based on disease severity. Which type of data does the Child-Pugh scoring system represent? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity and prognosis of chronic liver disease by categorizing patients into different classes based on specific criteria.
  • This score assigns patients to Class A, B, or C based on their total points, indicating varying levels of disease severity and prognosis.
  • It is an ordinal scale of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal: Incorrect. Nominal data involves categories without order, which does not apply to the ordered nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Option C. Qualitative: Incorrect. While the Child-Pugh score is qualitative in describing severity, the specific classification into ordered categories makes it ordinal.

 

Option D. Metric: Incorrect. Metric data involves quantitative measurements with consistent intervals, which does not describe the ordinal nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

 

14 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 14 Fr are commonly used in adult female patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Fr: 6 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 6 Fr are commonly used in pediatric patients or in adults with narrow urethras. They are also used in urodynamic studies to measure bladder pressures.

 

Option C. 16 Fr: 16 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 16 Fr are commonly used in adult male patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Option D. 22 Fr: 22 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 22 Fr are commonly used in patients for suprapubic cystostomy. They are also used in patients who have undergone prostate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FOLEY’S CATHETER

 

The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3rd mm.

choices.text: Diffuse alveolar damage

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath, persistent dry cough, and high fever for the past 8 days. He complains of severe fatigue and difficulty breathing even while resting. On examination, his temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), and his oxygen saturation is 80% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse bilateral crackles. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, and CT imaging confirms findings suggestive of severe COVID-19 pneumonia. Despite receiving supplemental oxygen, his condition rapidly deteriorates, and he requires intubation. Based on the most common lung pathology associated with severe COVID-19 infection, what is the primary lung abnormality observed?
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Diffuse Alveolar Damage

 

Explanation:

 

Diffuse Alveolar Damage (DAD) is the predominant lung pathology seen in severe COVID-19 pneumonia, particularly in those requiring intensive care or mechanical ventilation. It represents an acute injury to the lung parenchyma, leading to severe impairment of gas exchange.

 

Histopathological Features of DAD in COVID-19:

 

Early Phase (Exudative):

 

  • Intra-alveolar edema (fluid accumulation)
  • Endothelial cell necrosis (damage to the lining of blood vessels)
  • Microthrombosis (formation of small blood clots within vessels)
  • Endothelialitis (inflammation of blood vessel lining)

 

Later Phase (Proliferative):

 

  • Pneumocyte type 2 hyperplasia (increased number of cells responsible for surfactant production)
  • Intra-alveolar giant cells (abnormal large cells)
  • Hyaline membrane formation (protein-rich deposits lining alveoli)
  • Solid fibrin deposits (protein involved in blood clotting)
  • Thrombosis in small to medium-sized vessels

 

Clinical Impact

 

These changes result in a breakdown of the alveolar-capillary barrier, hindering oxygen transfer to the blood and causing severe hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels). This manifests as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), a life-threatening condition often seen in severe COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary abscess: A localized collection of pus within the lung, often caused by bacterial infection. While possible in COVID-19, it's not the primary pathology and doesn't explain the diffuse lung involvement.

 

Option C. Bronchiolitis obliterans: A chronic inflammatory condition leading to small airway obstruction. It's not typically associated with acute COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Option D. Interstitial lung disease: A group of conditions causing lung scarring. While COVID-19 can lead to long-term lung damage, the acute presentation is dominated by DAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage is the hallmark of severe COVID-19 lung injury, leading to ARDS and significant morbidity and mortality. Recognizing its key features helps understand the pathophysiology and clinical manifestations of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collar stud appearance  

 

The provided image depicts the right fundus of a patient, which indicates the presence of choroidal melanoma.

 

  • Angiography of the lesion: shows a distinct "double circulation" pattern, which represents the internal circulation within the tumor and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina.
  • On B-scan: pathognomonic feature called the "collar stud appearance" is visible. This appearance refers to a raised, dome-shaped tumor with a collar-like thickening at the base, caused by the accumulation of melanin and the infiltration of inflammatory cells at the tumor base.

 

 

Choroidal melanoma is a type of cancer that originates in the choroid, which is the vascular layer of the eye located between the retina and the sclera. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and can lead to visual impairment and even metastasis to other organs. Therefore, it is crucial to diagnose and manage it promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoke-stack appearance: Typically associated with central serous retinopathy, showing a smoke-like leakage of fluid under the retina.

 

Option B. Inkblot appearance: Another pattern seen in central serous retinopathy where fluid leaks in a blot-like fashion.

 

Option D. Double circulation: While this feature can be seen in angiography of choroidal melanoma, it does not describe the ultrasonography appearance, which is specifically asked in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.

choices.text: Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole
Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin
Candida albicans - Amphotericin B
Candida Krusei– Fluconazole

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida Krusei- Fluconazole

 

Candida Krusei is known to be intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, which is a widely used antifungal agent. This resistance is due to the specific genetic and biochemical characteristics of C. Kruse, which include efflux pumps that actively expel the drug and alterations in the target enzyme of fluconazole, making it less effective.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole: Aspergillus Niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole; in fact, voriconazole is one of the treatments of choice for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin: Aspergillus fumigatus is sensitive to echinocandins, including micafungin. It is not intrinsically resistant to this drug.

 

Option C. Candida albicans - Amphotericin B: Candida albicans is sensitive to amphotericin B, which is a broad-spectrum antifungal with a wide range of activity against various fungal species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with bleeding disorder, gives family history of her father and sister suffering from the same bleeding disorders. Which is the most likely disorder? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease is a common inherited bleeding disorder that affects both males and females, and it is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that males and females have an equal chance of inheriting the disorder from a parent, which is consistent with the family history provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: This is a X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males; females are typically carriers unless under rare circumstances.

 

Option C. Christmas Disease (Hemophilia B): Similar to Hemophilia A, this condition is also X-linked recessive, predominantly affecting males.

 

Option D. Factor 12 Deficiency: This is a much rarer condition and usually does not lead to significant bleeding issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand disease is characterized by its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects both genders, making it the most likely diagnosis for a female patient with a family history of bleeding disorders involving both male and female family members.

choices.text: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibiotics against hemidesmosomes

 

The given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The question talking about the false statement.

 

In direct immunofluorescence testing for pemphigus vulgaris, the immunoglobulin deposition is observed along the plasma membranes of epidermal keratinocytes in a reticular or fishnet-like pattern, indicating an autoantibody attack against desmosomal adhesion proteins. This results in early suprabasal separation and loss of cell-to-cell adhesion (acantholysis). The severity and position of the blisters are related to the distribution of desmoglein 1 and 3 in the epidermis and the presence of autoantibodies to one or both proteins. The antibodies primarily disrupt the intercellular adhesive function of the desmosomes and may activate intercellular proteases. The observed pattern is due to the interepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3. The Tzanck smear is the preferred initial test, which involves collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister for microscopic examination, using Giemsa or Romanowsky stain. The presence of Tzank cells confirms the diagnosis.

 

This is incorrect and hence the false statement. Hemidesmosomes are associated with a different condition called bullous pemphigoid, where autoantibodies target components of the basement membrane, not the desmosomes as in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibodies against desmoglein 3: This statement is true, as pemphigus vulgaris involves antibodies against desmoglein 3, particularly in mucosal lesions.

 

Option B. Antibodies against desmoglein 1: This statement is also true. Pemphigus vulgaris can involve antibodies against desmoglein 1, which is primarily found in the superficial layers of the skin.

 

Option C. Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature: This is correct, as pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by suprabasal blisters formed due to acantholysis, resulting from the disruption of desmosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by autoantibodies against desmosomal proteins (desmoglein 1 and 3), leading to a suprabasal acantholytic blister and a diagnostic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence.

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.text: You are a global health researcher working on a report assessing the development status of various countries. To classify the countries and compare them, you decide to use the Human Development Index (HDI). You recall that HDI is a commonly utilized measure but seek to clarify its exact components, as presented by organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO). Which of the following correctly identifies the components that make up the HDI? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living 

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels. It consists of three main components:

 

  • Life Expectancy at Birth: Measures the average number of years a newborn is expected to live.
  • Education (Literacy and Mean Years of Schooling): Assesses the average number of years of education received by people ages 25 and older and the expected years of schooling for children entering school.
  • Standard of Living (Gross National Income per capita): Adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).

 

Note -

 

  • HDI values range: 0 to + 1
  • HDI India is 0. 633 (Rank 134 out of 186 countries)
  • Human poverty index [HPI] is complementary to HDI

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: MEN1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1)
GHRHR (Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone Receptor)
PRKAR1A (Protein Kinase A Regulatory Subunit 1 Alpha)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of progressive changes in his physical appearance over the past five years. He notes that his hands and feet have grown larger, requiring new shoes and rings, and his facial features have become coarser, with an especially prominent jaw. He also reports increased sweating, frequent headaches, joint pain, and occasional blurred vision. On examination, he has enlarged hands with thickened, sausage-like fingers, a broad lower face, and a protruding jaw (mandibular prognathism). Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated levels of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). MRI of the brain shows a pituitary mass consistent with an adenoma. Based on the clinical presentation and findings, which gene is most likely implicated in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: A. PIT1 (POU1F1)

 

Explanation:

 

Mutations in the PIT1 (POU1F1) gene, a pituitary-specific transcription factor, can lead to the development of somatotroph adenomas that produce excessive growth hormone (GH). Elevated GH levels result in increased production of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), which is responsible for the characteristic features of acromegaly when these hormones are overproduced after the closure of growth plates. Acromegaly manifests with overgrowth of the skin, soft tissues, and viscera, including the thyroid, heart, and liver. The bones of the face, hands, and feet become thickened and enlarged, leading to a distinct appearance with prognathism and broadening of the lower face. Additional systemic complications include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, arthritis, and an increased risk of cardiovascular and gastrointestinal diseases.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. MEN1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1)


MEN1 gene mutations cause a syndrome involving multiple endocrine tumors, including those in the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary. Although pituitary adenomas can occur, they do not specifically explain the isolated somatotroph adenoma or the distinct acromegaly features linked to PIT1 dysregulation.

 

Option C. GHRHR (Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone Receptor)


Mutations in GHRHR can affect growth hormone regulation but typically do not lead to the development of somatotroph adenomas or the acromegaly features seen in this patient. GHRHR mutations often result in isolated growth hormone deficiency rather than hormone excess.

 

Option D. PRKAR1A (Protein Kinase A Regulatory Subunit 1 Alpha)


PRKAR1A mutations are associated with Carney complex, a condition involving spotty skin pigmentation, myxomas, and endocrine overactivity, including pituitary tumors. However, it does not specifically cause isolated somatotroph adenomas or the classic findings of acromegaly as seen with PIT1 mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PIT1 (POU1F1) is a critical transcription factor for pituitary somatotroph, lactotroph, and thyrotroph cells. Mutations in PIT1 can lead to pituitary adenomas that secrete excessive growth hormone, resulting in acromegaly characterized by enlarged extremities, coarse facial features, and other systemic complications such as hypertension, diabetes, and increased cardiovascular risk. Recognizing these features is essential for early diagnosis and targeted management of acromegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures does not form part of the laryngeal skeleton? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked as 'A', is the hyoid bone, which is not a part of the laryngeal skeleton.

 

The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located at the base of the tongue. While it is not considered a part of the larynx itself.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A - Hyoid bone

B - Thyroid cartilage

C - Epiglottis

D - Cricoid cartilage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid Cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is a large, shield-shaped cartilage in the larynx. It forms the prominent Adam's apple in the front of the neck and plays a role in sound production.

 

Option C. Epiglottis: The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilage  which belongs to larynx located at the base of the tongue. Its primary function is to prevent food and liquids from entering the airway (trachea) during swallowing.

 

Option D. Cricoid Cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located just below the thyroid cartilage. It is the only complete ring of cartilage in the larynx and provides structural support to the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A set of cartilages that are joined by ligaments and fibrous membranes make up the laryngeal skeleton:

 

  • Hyaline cartilage: The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages
  • Elastic cartilage: The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C) Insulinoma. These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • It is associated with the overproduction of gastrin, which leads to excessive stomach acid production.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

 

Option D. VIPoma:

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

choices.text: Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
RBC lysis due to hemoglobinopathy
Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presented in December with chronic fatigue, cyanosis of the nose, blue lips, and arthralgia. A peripheral blood smear is provided. What is the most likely cause of these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia

 

Explanation: The patient's symptoms and the blood smear results suggest cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia (CAIHA), typically mediated by IgM antibodies. These antibodies lead to agglutination of red blood cells (RBCs) in cold conditions, which are visible as clumps in the smear. This type of anemia is characterized by the presence of IgM antibodies that bind to RBCs at temperatures below normal body temperature and cause agglutination and hemolysis upon rewarming, particularly in peripheral areas like the nose and lips.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. IgG mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This option is incorrect because IgG antibodies are usually associated with warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia, not cold.
  • Option C. RBC lysis due to hemoglobinopathy: Hemoglobinopathies typically cause morphological abnormalities in RBCs, not agglutination.
  • Option D. Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves IgG antibodies that act at body temperature and do not cause symptoms that worsen with cold exposure.

 

Educational Objectives: Cold agglutinin disease, a type of cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia, should be suspected in patients with acrocyanosis (bluish discoloration of extremities) and symptoms that worsen with cold exposure, confirmed by blood smear showing RBC clumping at low temperatures.

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can be transmitted through various means, including sexual contact, from mother to child during childbirth, and through blood transfusions. Syphilis can be transmitted by all components of the blood, making it a comprehensive risk in blood transfusion contexts.

 

While other infections like hepatitis B and C, malaria, and HIV can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, the question specifically asks for an STD. Among the options given, syphilis is the only STD that fits this criterion.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: Incorrect because while hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through blood transfusions, they are not classified primarily as sexually transmitted diseases.

 

Option B. Filariasis: Incorrect because filariasis is a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, not through blood transfusions or as an STD.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect because malaria is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes and through blood transfusions, but it is not an STD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is an STD that can be transmitted by all components of the blood, highlighting the importance of thorough blood screening.

questions.text: Which parameters would you utilize to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programmer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Annual Blood Examination Rate

 

Annual blood examination rate (ABER): (Index of operational efficiency)

 

 

 

ABER is a critical parameter used to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program. It reflects the proportion of the population that is being tested for malaria and helps determine the operational efficiency of the surveillance system. High ABER indicates effective surveillance and control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual parasitic incidence (API): Sophisticated measure of malaria incidence in a community

 

 

Option C. Slide positivity rate (SPR):

 

 

Option D. Slide falciparum rate: specifically measures the proportion of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum, the most severe form of malaria. It indicates the burden of P. falciparum in the population.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old resident physician was exposed to HIV through a needlestick injury and has come to the emergency department seeking help. You decide to start her on post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Which of the following drug combinations is most recommended for PEP in this scenario? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is an emergency treatment for HIV exposure, typically recommended to be started as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 2 hours and no later than 72 hours.
  • The choice of antiretroviral therapy for PEP should be guided by current recommendations that prioritize effectiveness and tolerability.
  • Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir (Option B): This combination is currently recommended for PEP due to its high efficacy, good tolerability, and strong safety profile. Tenofovir and Lamivudine provide a potent backbone of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), while Dolutegravir acts as an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), which has a rapid onset of action and is well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Duration of prophylaxis is 28 days

questions.text:
A patient complains of persistent, dull, aching pain in both legs. He reports a history of extended periods of standing and mentions having visibly twisted veins in his legs. What tests would typically be conducted to assess saphenofemoral incompetence in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Brodie Trendelenburg Test
  2. Morrissey's test
  3. Fegan's test
  4. Modified Perthes test
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

The Brodie Trendelenburg and Morrissey's tests aim to assess the competency of the saphenofemoral valve, while the Fegan's method is utilized to identify perforator incompetence. Meanwhile, the Modified Perthe's test serves as a diagnostic measure for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

 

1. Brodie–Trendelenburg Test:  The affected leg is raised so that the veins are emptied by gravity. Around the upper thigh region, a tourniquet is applied, sufficiently tightly to constrict the saphenous vein. The femoral vein blood flow isn’t obstructed. The patient is then asked to stand and the degree of filling of the saphenous vein is noted. On release of tourniquet, rapid filling of great saphenous vein is noted from above downwards in case of saphenofemoral junction incompetence.

 

2. Morrissey’s cough impulse test: Limb is elevated to empty the veins and then patient is asked to cough. An expansile impulse is felt on palpation at saphenofemoral junction.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Fegan's test: This is method is used to identify perforator incompetence. Site where perforators pierce deep fascia bulges on standing and depresses on lying supine, which can be felt as defects in deep fascia.

 

4. Modified Perthes test: This test is done to rule out Deep vein thrombosis. First veins are emptied and a tourniquet is placed around the thigh and then instructed to stand up. Then patient is asked to rapidly stand up and down on their toes and walk quickly for a few minutes. If filling of veins is observed, then this indicates Deep vein thrombosis. This is a painful test and is rarely used.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma

 

The presence of empty appearing nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

 

  • Histological Appearance: Papillary carcinoma has a papillary growth pattern with branching papillae composed of fibrovascular stalks and cuboidal epithelial cells.
  • Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei: Papillary carcinoma cells have distinct Orphan Annie eye nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and an optically clear or empty appearance.
  • Psammoma Bodies: Papillary carcinoma often contains psammoma bodies, which are concentrically calcified structures found within the papillae.
  • Lymphatic Invasion: Papillary carcinoma commonly exhibits lymphatic invasion; involvement of blood vessels is uncommon.
  • Genetic Alterations: Papillary carcinoma is associated with specific genetic changes, including gene rearrangements like RET/PTC and NTRK1, as well as BRAF gene mutations.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular carcinoma: This is incorrect. Follicular carcinoma typically presents with a different histological pattern, characterized by small follicles. It does not exhibit Orphan Annie eye nuclei, which are specific to papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Toxic nodular goitre: This is incorrect. Toxic nodular goitre, or multinodular goitre, is a benign condition and does not present with Orphan Annie eye nuclei or the other specific histological features of papillary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma: This is incorrect. Medullary carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and is characterized by amyloid deposits and the presence of calcitonin, rather than the histological features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on histopathological examination is a key diagnostic feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in laparoscopic surgery? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The Veress needle is an instrument displayed in the image that is utilized to inflate the abdomen for laparoscopic surgery. In laparoscopic procedures, there are two ways of establishing abdominal access: the direct puncture technique (closed technique) and the open technique. The Veress needle is specifically used in the direct puncture laparoscopy method.

 

Lind's Needle: Lind's needle is a type of trocar and cannula system used in medical procedures, particularly for draining fluids or inserting catheters. It consists of a sharp, pointed needle (the trocar) that is enclosed within a cannula.

questions.text: You're a physician attending a conference on emerging infectious diseases. As the discussion shifts towards the recent outbreaks in South India, the speaker displays an image showcasing the life cycle of a specific virus. A fellow physician sitting beside you, being relatively unfamiliar with the recent disease trends in South India, asks for your insights about the virus in question. Given the depicted life cycle and the associated clinical syndromes, which of the following viruses would be the most likely culprit? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Nipah virus

 

NIPAH Virus

 

  • Genus: Henapi virus
  • Transmission in India:
    • Occurrence: West Bengal, Kerela (Kozhikode district)
    • Route: Consumption of fruits contaminated with bats (Pteropus: ‘Flying foxes’) secretions (person - person in India) 
    • Direct contact with infected bats, infected pigs, infected people
  • Clinical presentation: Encephalitis
  • IP is 4-14 days
  • Case fatality rate: 50%
  • Vaccine: NONE for humans
  • Treatment: Intensive supportive care
    • High-risk contacts and healthcare workers, who are under quarantine and monitoring for 21 days
  • WHO included Nipah virus under list of Emerging Diseases likely to cause Major Epidemics 
  • Comes under Category C of Bioterrorism agent 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Japanese encephalitis: Transmitted by mosquitoes and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Option B. Zika virus: Transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily the Aedes species, and does not match the transmission cycle shown in the image.

 

ZIKA VIRUS LIFE CYCLE

 

 

 

Option C. Rabies: Transmitted through the bites of infected animals (typically dogs or other mammals) and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nipah virus, transmitted through fruit bats and causing encephalitis, fits the transmission cycle shown in the image and is a significant emerging infectious disease in regions such as Malaysia and Bangladesh.

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow examination

 

The next investigation of choice, in a child suspected to have a chloroma, is a bone marrow biopsy.

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localised tumour forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumour is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

Frequent sites of involvement are the skin, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal tract, bone, soft tissue, testis, and peritoneum. Isolated orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The diagnosis of AML is based on the presence of at least 20% myeloid blasts in the bone marrow.

 

Although myeloid sarcomas are radiosensitive, they are managed with systemic chemotherapy in most cases, even in the absence of bone marrow involvement. Surgery and/or radiation therapy may be indicated for symptomatic lesions or tumors causing local organ dysfunction or obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet count: While important in assessing overall hematologic status, platelet count alone is not sufficient to diagnose chloroma or AML.

 

Option B. WBC count: Similarly, WBC count is part of the complete blood count but does not provide the definitive diagnosis needed in this case.

 

Option C. Flow cytometry: This test can help classify leukemia subtypes by analyzing cell surface markers but is typically performed after a bone marrow examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected chloroma in the context of AML, a bone marrow examination is the critical next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1150-1154

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with. He also reports night sweats and significant unintentional weight loss.. Serum tumor markers, including alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG), are elevated. A biopsy confirms an extragonadal germ cell tumor. What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor?
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Mediastinum

 

Explanation:

 

The mediastinum is the most common site for extragonadal germ cell tumors, accounting for 50-70% of these cases, particularly in young males. These tumors develop from ectopic germ cells that fail to migrate correctly during embryogenesis and become trapped in the mediastinum, where they can proliferate. Symptoms often include chest pain, cough, and dyspnea due to the mass effect, along with systemic symptoms like night sweats and weight loss. The presence of elevated serum tumor markers such as AFP and β-hCG aids in diagnosis, confirmed by imaging and biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver


The liver is not a common primary site for extragonadal germ cell tumors. Tumors found in the liver are typically metastatic rather than primary extragonadal germ cell tumors, making it an unlikely location for this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Adrenal glands


The adrenal glands are not a typical site for extragonadal germ cell tumors. Tumors in the adrenal region are more likely to be adrenal adenomas, pheochromocytomas, or metastatic lesions rather than primary germ cell tumors.

 

Option C. Paraspinal region


While paraspinal masses can occur, they are more commonly neurogenic tumors, such as schwannomas or neuroblastomas, rather than extragonadal germ cell tumors. Germ cell tumors in this area are rare compared to the mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mediastinum is the most common site for extragonadal germ cell tumors, accounting for 50-70% of cases, particularly in young males. These tumors arise due to misplaced germ cells during embryogenesis and often present with symptoms related to the mass effect, such as chest pain, cough, and dyspnea, alongside elevated tumor markers like AFP and β-hCG. Recognizing the mediastinum as the primary site is essential for proper diagnosis and management.

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient on medication presents with the lab values as shown below. (INICET MAY 2022)

 

Which of the following drugs should be stopped?
 

K+ :6.5 meg/L

Na+ :137 meg/L

Urea: 42 mg/dL

Creatinine: 3.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. Losartan
 

Let's analyze the lab values and determine which medication, if any, should be stopped:

 

  1. Elevated Potassium (K+): A potassium level of 6.5 mEq/L is higher than the normal range (usually around 3.5 to 5.0 mEq/L). High potassium levels, known as hyperkalemia, can be a concern, especially for patients taking certain medications that can affect potassium levels.
  2. Normal Sodium (Na+): A sodium level of 137 mEq/L falls within the normal range. There is no immediate concern regarding sodium levels.
  3. Elevated Urea and Creatinine: Urea and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating impaired kidney function. This is a significant concern, as it may suggest that the kidneys are not effectively filtering waste products from the blood.

 

Considering the elevated potassium level and impaired kidney function (elevated urea and creatinine), it is important to stop any drug that causes hyperkalemia. Among the given drugs, losartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker (ARB), which can lead to hyperkalemia by blocking the action of the RAAS pathway. Since this patient has developed Hyperkalemia, Losartan should be stopped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker used for hypertension. It does not typically affect potassium levels and does not need to be stopped in this scenario.

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: A thiazide diuretic used for hypertension. It usually causes hypokalemia (low potassium levels), not hyperkalemia. Therefore, it does not need to be stopped in this case.

 

Option D. Furosemide: A loop diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension. Furosemide usually causes hypokalemia and can actually be used to help lower elevated potassium levels. Hence, it should not be stopped and might even be beneficial in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a hypertensive patient with hyperkalemia and impaired kidney function, Losartan should be stopped due to its potential to exacerbate hyperkalemia. Amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and furosemide do not typically increase potassium levels and do not need to be stopped. In fact, furosemide may help in lowering the elevated potassium levels.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. Ultrasound revealed a 2 cm x 2 cm nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid, extending into the strap muscles. The histopathology image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Papillary cancer of thyroid

 

The clinical scenario and the image showing papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei indicate a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

 

Histologically, the following features are present

 

  1. Papillary pattern - Papillae composed of fibrovascular stalk and covered by single layer of tumor cells is the predominant feature. Papillae are often accompanied by follicles.
  2. Tumor cells. The tumor cells have characteristic nuclear features due to dispersed nuclear chromatin imparting it ground glass or optically clear appearance and clear or oxyphilic cytoplasm also called Orphan Annie nuclei.
  3. Invasion - Invade the capsule and intra-thyroid lymphatics
  4. Psammoma bodies - Small, concentric, calcified spherules called psammoma bodies in the stroma.

 

Papillary carcinoma thyroid microscopy shows branching papillae having fibrovascular stalk covered by a single layer of cuboidal cells having ground nuclei. Colloid-filled follicles and sloid sheets of tumor cells are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary cancer of thyroid: This cancer arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid and is associated with elevated calcitonin levels. Histologically, it shows a solid growth pattern with amyloid deposits, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Follicular cancer of thyroid: This type of thyroid cancer typically shows a follicular growth pattern with invasion into blood vessels or the capsule. The cells do not have the distinct nuclear features (Orphan Annie nuclei) seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Thyroglossal cyst: This is a benign cystic lesion that usually presents as a midline neck mass that moves with swallowing or tongue protrusion. It does not present with a nodule in the thyroid gland or the histological features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized by Orphan Annie nuclei, psammoma bodies, and a papillary architecture, which are key diagnostic features.

choices.text: Prostate carcinoma
Breast carcinoma
Stomach carcinoma

questions.text: Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostate carcinoma

 

Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in prostate carcinoma.

 

Metastatic bone tumors: Metastatic bone tumors outnumber primary bone cancers as the most common type of skeletal malignancy.

 

Osteoblastic (or sclerotic) bone deposition is seen in prostate cancer, carcinoid, small cell lung cancer, Hodgkin lymphoma, and medulloblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast carcinoma: While breast cancer can metastasize to bone, it typically results in osteolytic (bone-destroying) rather than osteoblastic lesions.

 

Option C. Stomach carcinoma: Metastases from stomach cancer to bone are relatively rare and typically do not exhibit osteoblastic activity.

 

Option D. Bone carcinoma: This option is less specific and generally refers to primary bone cancers, which are different from the metastatic osteoblastic lesions seen in prostate cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoblastic metastases are a hallmark of prostate carcinoma, unlike breast and stomach carcinomas which are more likely to cause osteolytic or no bone lesions respectively.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Neurosecretory bodies except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adrenal cortical tumor

 

Neurosecretory bodies are not seen in adrenal cortical tumors.

 

Adrenocortical neoplasms produce aldosterone. Primary hyperaldosteronism due to a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma is Conn syndrome.

 

Microscopically, aldosterone-producing adenomas show spironolactone bodies which are eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions found after treatment with spironolactone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C-cells, which are neuroendocrine cells. These cells secrete calcitonin and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Option B. Pituitary adenoma: Pituitary adenomas are tumors of the pituitary gland, many of which are neuroendocrine in nature. They can produce hormones such as prolactin, growth hormone, or ACTH, and neurosecretory granules can be found in these tumors.

 

Option C. Paraganglioma: Paragangliomas are tumors that arise from paraganglia, which are collections of neuroendocrine cells. These cells are closely related to the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurosecretory bodies are associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but not with adrenal cortical tumors, which originate from the adrenal cortex and are involved in steroid hormone production.

 

Tumors associated with neurosecretory granules

choices.text: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries
Can be diagnosed with CECT
Improves with food rich in carbohydrates
Increased risk of GI lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following is true about celiac disease? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased risk of GI lymphoma

 

Individuals with celiac disease have an increased risk of Gl lymphoma.

 

Celiac disease is also known as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is an immune mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing cereals, such as barley, rye, oats & wheat (BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals. In countries where most people are Caucasians of European ancestry, celiac disease is a common disorder, with an estimated prevalence of 0.5% to 1%.

 

The histopathology is characterized by increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy. This loss of mucosal and brush-border surface area accounts for the malabsorption.

 

 

Noninvasive serologic tests are generally performed prior to biopsy. The most sensitive tests are the presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin. Anti-endomysial antibodies are highly specific but less sensitive than other antibodies.

 

Individuals with celiac disease have a higher-than-normal rate of malignancy. The most common celiac disease–associated cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes. Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

 

The treatment is lifelong gluten free diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries: This is incorrect. While celiac disease can cause malnutrition due to malabsorption, it is not the most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries. Infectious diseases, poor diet, and other factors are more common causes.

 

Option B. Can be diagnosed with CECT: This is incorrect. Celiac disease is not typically diagnosed with contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT). The diagnosis is usually based on serologic tests for specific antibodies and confirmed by duodenal biopsy showing characteristic histopathological changes such as villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis.

 

Option C. Improves with food rich in carbohydrates: This is incorrect. Celiac disease improves with a gluten-free diet, not with an increase in carbohydrates. The treatment requires strict lifelong avoidance of gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is associated with an increased risk of gastrointestinal lymphoma, specifically enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, making it a critical long-term concern for individuals with this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1518-1519

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

 

The cell of origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) is either naïve B cells or post-germinal centre memory B cell.

 

 

 

FCL = Follicular Cell Lymphoma; MALT = Marginal Zone Lymphoma of Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue; MCL = Mantle Cell Lymphoma; SLL/CLL = Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mature B cells: While mature B cells can give rise to certain types of lymphomas, CLL/SLL specifically arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells.

 

Option B. Mature T cells: Mature T cells are associated with different types of lymphomas, such as T-cell lymphomas, not CLL/SLL.

 

Option C. Progenitor T cells: Progenitor T cells are involved in the development of T-cell leukemias and lymphomas, such as T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not CLL/SLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulin

 

Tubulin is a part of microtubules and is not an intermediate filament.

 

The intermediate filaments comprise the major component of the cytoskeleton and consist of five major subgroups—vimentin, keratins, desmin, neurofilaments, and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)—and a small number of minor subgroups (e.g., nestin, peripherin).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vimentin: Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein commonly found in cells of mesenchymal origin. It helps maintain cellular integrity and provides resistance to stress.

 

Option C. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein found predominantly in muscle cells. It is crucial for maintaining the structural integrity of muscle cells by linking the cytoskeletal network to the sarcomere.

 

Option D. Neurofilament: Neurofilaments are intermediate filaments found in neurons. They are important for maintaining the shape and strength of nerve cells and play a role in the conduction of nerve impulses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulin is not an intermediate filament; it is a protein that forms microtubules, which are essential for cell shape, motility, and division. Intermediate filaments, such as vimentin, desmin, and neurofilaments, provide mechanical support and structural integrity to cells.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding sirtuins? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity.
  3. They are of 7 types.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Sirtuins are a family of proteins that have been widely studied for their role in regulating various cellular processes, including aging, metabolism, and stress responses. Here's a detailed breakdown of each statement:

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism: Sirtuins, particularly SIRT1, have been shown to enhance insulin sensitivity and promote glucose metabolism, which is crucial for maintaining energy homeostasis.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity: Sirtuins are known to regulate gene expression in ways that promote longevity. They are involved in the deacetylation of proteins that contribute to cell survival, repair, and metabolism, which are associated with extended lifespan in various organisms.
