  3. They are of 7 types: There are seven known sirtuins in humans, designated SIRT1 through SIRT7, each with specific functions in different cellular compartments.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases: Sirtuins function as NAD+-dependent deacetylases, a class of enzymes that remove acetyl groups from histone and non-histone proteins, influencing gene expression and protein activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, promoting genes associated with longevity, and playing a significant role in various cellular processes.

choices.text: Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes
Clear colorless to pale yellow

questions.text: Which of the following are the features of the color of normal amniotic fluid during? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clear colorless to pale yellow

 

Explanation:

 

The color of normal amniotic fluid varies during pregnancy and can indicate different conditions:

 

  • In early pregnancy: The amniotic fluid is colorless.
  • Near term: It becomes straw-colored.
  • Deep yellow/golden color: This can indicate fetal anemia.
  • Green (meconium-stained): Indicates fetal distress or post-maturity.
  • Red: Suggests abruption.
  • Dark colored/tobacco-like: Indicates fetal demise.

 

Normal amniotic fluid should be clear, colorless, or pale yellow, especially in the earlier stages of pregnancy and near term when the fluid changes to a straw color.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes: This description is not characteristic of normal amniotic fluid. Such a color can indicate the presence of infection or contamination.

 

Option B. Amber colored: Amber-colored amniotic fluid is not a normal finding and may indicate complications such as the presence of blood or other abnormalities.

 

Option D. Golden color: Golden-colored amniotic fluid typically indicates fetal anemia, which is a pathological condition and not a feature of normal amniotic fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal amniotic fluid is clear, colorless to pale yellow, changing to straw-colored near term.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 43, William’s text book of obstetrics 24th edition pg 298

questions.text: Which of the following bands will increase in serum electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 2 globulin

 

 

  • In Nephrotic syndrome, there is a marked increase in alpha 2 globulin levels on serum electrophoresis. This is due to the liver increasing production of some proteins as a compensatory response to heavy proteinuria, especially proteins like alpha 2 macroglobulin, which are too large to be lost through the glomerulus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma globulin: Typically decreased or normal in Nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of smaller immunoglobulins in the urine.

 

Option C. Beta globulin: Generally shows little change in Nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Albumin: Markedly decreased in Nephrotic syndrome due to loss in the urine, which is a hallmark of the disease and responsible for the characteristic edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Nephrotic syndrome, Alpha 2 globulin increases on serum electrophoresis as a response to heavy proteinuria, while albumin significantly decreases leading to symptoms such as severe swelling and fluid accumulation in the body.

questions.text: All of the following can be used to decreased intraocular pressure in glaucoma except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dexamethasone

 

Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid. Corticosteroids are contraindicated in glaucoma because they can lead to an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). This rise in IOP can exacerbate glaucoma and potentially cause further damage to the optic nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is the drug of choice for acute congestive glaucoma when administered intravenously. It decreases IOP by creating an osmotic gradient, which helps to draw fluid out of the eye, thereby reducing congestion.

 

Option B. Methazolamide: Methazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It decreases the production of aqueous humor in the eye, which in turn reduces intraocular pressure. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are effective in managing glaucoma.

 

Option C. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. Alpha-2 agonists are commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma.

  

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - Dexamethasone is contraindicated in glaucoma

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 318, 167, 170

questions.text: Which of the following causes vasodilation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histamine  

 

The most important mast cell–derived amine is histamine. Histamine causes intense smooth muscle contraction, increased vascular permeability, and increased mucus secretion by nasal, bronchial, and gastric glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thromboxane A2: Thromboxane A2 is an activator of platelet aggregation and vasoconstrictor.

 

Option C. Serotonin: Serotonin possesses both vasoconstrictor and vasodilator properties.

 

Option D. Leukotrienes C4: Leukotrienes C4 and D4 are the most potent vasoactive and spasmogenic agents known. On a molar basis, they are several thousand times more active than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing bronchial smooth muscle contraction. Leukotriene B4 is highly chemotactic for neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is the primary mediator responsible for causing vasodilation, playing a critical role in the inflammatory response by increasing blood flow and vascular permeability.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia with halothane. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suxamethonium

 

The scenario described involves a patient undergoing surgery who suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. This is indicative of a condition called Malignant Hyperthermia (MH), which is a rare but potentially life-threatening reaction to certain medications used during anesthesia.

 

In this case, the most likely drug implicated in causing MH is:

 

Suxamethonium (also known as succinylcholine)

 

  • Suxamethonium is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used for muscle relaxation during surgery.
  • However, it is known to be associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals.
  • MH is a severe reaction that can cause a rapid increase in body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other complications.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Doxacurium: Doxacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used to induce muscle relaxation during surgery. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Atracurium: Atracurium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Rocuronium is also a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Like atracurium and doxacurium, it is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug most likely implicated in causing malignant hyperthermia in the given scenario is suxamethonium (succinylcholine) because it is known to trigger this condition in susceptible individuals.

 

Treatment - Dantrolene sodium and supportive management

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
B12 deficiency
Hereditary spherocytosis
Acute myeloid leukemia

questions.text: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear given below? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B12 deficiency

 

The peripheral smear provided shows the presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. These findings are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, which is most commonly caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate.

 

  • Macro-ovalocytes are large, oval-shaped red blood cells that result from impaired DNA synthesis, which occurs in megaloblastic anemia.
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils are neutrophils with more than the normal number of nuclear lobes (usually more than five). This is a classic finding in vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to impaired DNA synthesis, causing ineffective erythropoiesis and resulting in the release of abnormally large red blood cells (macro-ovalocytes) and hypersegmented neutrophils into the circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: This typically presents with microcytic hypochromic red blood cells, not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option C. Hereditary spherocytosis: This condition is characterized by the presence of spherocytes (small, round, dense red blood cells) and not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia: AML is characterized by the presence of blasts in the peripheral blood smear, which are immature white blood cells, not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils in a peripheral smear is indicative of B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are included in qSOFA score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SBP, RR, GCS score

 

  • The Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score is used to identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit.
  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria:
    1. Respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min: A high respiratory rate indicates respiratory distress and a higher risk of organ failure.
    2. Systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg: Low blood pressure indicates hemodynamic instability and a higher risk of mortality.
    3. Change in mental status (GCS score): Altered mental status, measured by the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), indicates possible central nervous system dysfunction.
  • Each criterion is assigned one point, and a qSOFA score of ≥2 suggests a higher risk of adverse outcomes and increased mortality.

 

qSOFA (Quick SOFA) Criteria

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP, RR, and CBC: This option includes blood pressure and respiratory rate, but the complete blood count (CBC) is not part of the qSOFA score.

 

Option B. Creatinine, PR, BP:  Creatinine and pulse rate (PR) are not part of the qSOFA score. Blood pressure is included, but the qSOFA score focuses on systolic blood pressure specifically.

 

Option C. RR, Body temperature, PR: Respiratory rate is part of the qSOFA score, but body temperature and pulse rate are not included.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria: respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg, and altered mental status (GCS score).
  • A qSOFA score of ≥2 indicates a higher risk of poor outcomes in patients with suspected infection.

questions.text: What does the following image show? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emperipolesis

 

The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage. In this case, a band neutrophil is seen inside a megakaryocyte.

 

A rare biological phenomenon called emperipolesis involves a cell penetrating another live cell. In emperipolesis, as opposed to phagocytosis, when the enveloped cell is destroyed by the macrophage's lysosomal enzymes, the cell can exit at any time without causing any structural or functional problems for either of them. This process can be either physiological or pathological. Histiocytes and Megakaryocytes generally participate in peripolesis. It is seen in Rosai-Dorfman disease and Hodgkin's disease are pathological circumstances when this process is observed.

 

NOTE:

 

Emperipolesis vs Entosis:

 

Emperipolesis is a cellular process in which one cell enters into another cell without being degraded or destroyed. This process occurs in various cell types, including immune cells and cancer cells, and is thought to play a role in cell-to-cell communication and immune surveillance. In emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell after a certain period of time.

 

Entosis, on the other hand, is a cellular process in which one cell actively engulfs and digests another cell. This process occurs primarily in epithelial cells and is thought to play a role in tissue homeostasis and elimination of damaged or excess cells. In Entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell's lysosomes.

 

In summary, the main difference between emperipolesis and Entosis is that in emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell, while in Entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autophagy: This process involves the degradation of a cell's own components through the lysosomal machinery.

 

Option C. Phagocytosis: The process by which a cell engulfs and digests foreign particles or cells, typically leading to the degradation of the engulfed material.

 

Option D. Amoebic autophagy: Not a recognized term; may be confused with autophagy or phagocytosis processes seen in amoebas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emperipolesis is a unique process where one cell enters another without being destroyed, differentiating it from phagocytosis and entosis, with the host cell usually being a megakaryocyte or histiocyte.

choices.text: Anthracotic pigment

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anthracotic pigment

 

The black pigment in the resected bronchoscopic specimen's hilar lymph node is most likely an anthracotic pigment.

 

The black colour is caused by carbon particle deposition. Carbon particles inhaled are engulfed by lung macrophages and transported to the hilar lymph nodes. This builds up and causes anthracosis, or blackening of the lung tissues.

 

 

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments with high levels of carbon particle pollution, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in humans as a result of urban air pollution. The aggregates of the carbon dust may induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanin: Melanin is a natural pigment found in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Lipochrome: Lipochrome (also known as lipofuscin) is a yellow-brown pigment that accumulates with age in various tissues, but it does not present as black and is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex and presents as a golden-brown pigment. It is associated with hemorrhage and iron metabolism but does not appear as black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anthracotic pigment, resulting from the deposition of carbon particles, is the most likely cause of the black pigment observed in the hilar lymph node of a patient with squamous cell carcinoma. This is common in individuals exposed to high levels of environmental pollution or occupational hazards involving carbon particles.

choices.text: Fixes cells to the slide
Stains the DNA of the parasite
Enhances the visibility of parasites
Prevents red blood cell hemolysis

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the clinic with a two-month history of intermittent fever, significant weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly and pallor. Laboratory investigations show pancytopenia, leading the physician to suspect visceral leishmaniasis. To confirm the diagnosis, a blood smear is prepared and stained using Leishman stain. During the staining process, the physician explains to a medical student the use of acetone-free methanol in the procedure. The student is curious about its specific role in the staining process. What role does acetone-free methanol play in this staining process?
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Fixes cells to the slide

 

Explanation:

 

Acetone-free methanol is used in Leishman stains primarily to fix cells to the slide. Fixation is a crucial step in preparing blood smears as it preserves the cellular architecture by denaturing proteins and adhering cells, including parasites, firmly to the slide. This fixation prevents the cells from washing away during subsequent staining steps and maintains their morphology, allowing for accurate visualization under the microscope. Using acetone-free methanol specifically avoids the dehydration and distortion that acetone-containing fixatives might cause, ensuring the cells remain intact and identifiable during the diagnostic process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stains the DNA of the parasite


Staining of the parasite's DNA is accomplished by the dyes within Leishman stain, such as methylene blue and eosin, which bind to nucleic acids and proteins, highlighting the parasite structures. Methanol’s role is purely in the fixation process and does not contribute directly to the staining of DNA.

 

Option C. Enhances the visibility of parasites


The enhancement of parasite visibility is mainly due to the contrasting action of the stains, which differentially color the parasites and cellular components, making them more visible. Methanol does not enhance visibility but ensures that the structures remain attached to the slide during staining.

 

Option D. Prevents red blood cell hemolysis


Methanol does not specifically prevent hemolysis of red blood cells; rather, it fixes the cells to the slide to preserve their morphology. Hemolysis prevention is more reliant on careful sample handling and the staining technique rather than the fixative used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetone-free methanol in Leishman's stain serves primarily to fix cells to the slide, preserving their morphology by stabilizing cellular proteins and adhering them firmly to the surface. This fixation step is critical to maintain the integrity of blood smears during staining, allowing accurate microscopic identification of cellular components and parasites such as Leishmania.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease

 

Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis seen in Kimmelstiel Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

 

These lesions are specific for type 1 diabetes (juvenile onset diabetes) or islet cell antibody-positive diabetes mellitus.

 

The pathologic changes consist of one or more nodules in a few or many glomeruli. Nodule is an ovoid or spherical, laminated, hyaline, acellular mass located within a lobule of the glomerulus.

 

The nodules are surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillary loops which may have normal or thickened GBM. The nodules are PAS-positive and contain lipid and fibrin. These nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman's capsules (“capsular drops”).

 

 

As the nodular lesions enlarge, they compress the glomerular capillaries and obliterate the glomerular tuft. As a result of glomerular and arteriolar involvement, renal ischemia occurs leading to tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis and grossly small, contracted kidney.

 

Renal failure is the second common cause of death in diabetes mellitus, the first being myocardial infarction.

 

Diabetic nephropathy encompasses 4 types of renal lesions in diabetes mellitus:

 

1. Diabetic glomerulosclerosis (Diffuse/ Nodular)

 

  1. Diffuse lesions are characterized by diffuse involvement of the glomeruli showing thickening of the GBM and diffuse increase in the mesangial matrix with mild proliferation of mesangial cells and exudative lesions (fibrin caps and capsular drops)
  2. Nodular lesion (Kimmelstiel-Wilson Lesion) is characterized by one or more hyaline nodules within the lobules of glomeruli, surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillaries with thickened walls.

 

 

2.  Vascular lesions – Hyaline arterioslerosis

Morphology

 

 

3. Diabetic pyelonephritis – Papillary necrosis / Necrotizing papillitis

 

4. Tubular lesions (Armanni-Ebstein lesions).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal amyloidosis: Amyloidosis presents with amyloid deposits, typically visualized using Congo red stain, which is different from the PAS-positive nodules seen in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli and does not present with the diffuse nodular glomerulosclerosis observed in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option D. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis involves immune complex deposition, which leads to a different set of histological changes, including "wire loop" lesions, which are not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, a specific form of diabetic nephropathy, is characterized by PAS-positive nodules within the glomeruli, often associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 2206

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

The clinical presentation of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction in a young child, along with the histopathological image from the cardiac biopsy, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

 

Lymphocytic Myocarditis:

 

  • Pathology: Characterized by interstitial inflammation with a predominance of lymphocytes. The image provided shows myocardial fibers with an interstitial infiltrate primarily composed of lymphocytes. Associated myocyte necrosis
  • Etiology: Commonly caused by viral infections such as coxsackievirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus B19.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with signs and symptoms of heart failure, arrhythmias, and systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Typically shows Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells on biopsy, which are not present in the provided image.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by amastigotes in myocardial cells, often with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, not just lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Pyogenic myocarditis: Characterized by the presence of neutrophils, indicating bacterial infection, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

 

 

Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

 

Hypersensitivity myocarditis

 

 

Giant cell myocarditis

 

 

Myocarditis of Chagas disease (arrow showing trypanosomes)

questions.text: Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) recognizes? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipids without MHC proteins

 

  • A small population of mature T cells expresses a type of TCR composed of γ and δ polypeptide chains. The γδ TCR recognizes peptides, lipids, and small molecules, without a requirement for display by MHC proteins. γδ T cells tend to aggregate at epithelial surfaces, such as the skin and mucosa of the gastrointestinal and urogenital tracts, suggesting that these cells are sentinels that protect against microbes that try to enter through epithelia
  • The αβ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are displayed by major histocompatibility complex (MHC. molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). By limiting the specificity of T cells for peptides displayed by cell surface MHC molecules, called MHC restriction, the immune system ensures that T cells see only cell-associated antigens (e.g., those derived from microbes in cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peptides with MHC proteins: This is characteristic of αβ TCRs, not γδ TCRs.

 

Option C. CD20: CD20 is a B cell marker, not a target recognized by T cell receptors.

 

Option D. CD3: CD3 is a signaling molecule associated with the T cell receptor complex but is not a specific target recognized by the TCR itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) are unique in that they can recognize lipids and other molecules without the need for MHC protein presentation, distinguishing them from the more common αβ T cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 353

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anemia and hemoglobinuria. Investigations reveal increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following physical examination findings can support the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mechanical second heart sound

 

The above scenario, which includes anemia, increased LDH, and hemoglobinuria, as well as schistocytes on a peripheral smear, is suggestive of angiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) caused by red cell trauma. A mechanical second heart sound can help to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a type of hemolytic anemia caused by red cell trauma.

 

Shear forces cause hemolysis in artificial mechanical cardiac valves due to turbulent blood flow and pressure gradients. This traumatic damage causes intravascular hemolysis and the appearance in blood smears of red cell fragments (schistocytes), burr cells, helmet cells, and triangle cells. The same pressure gradients are also responsible for a mechanical heart sound on auscultation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenomegaly: Splenomegaly is often seen in various hemolytic anemias but is not specific for MAHA associated with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option B. Frontal bossing: Frontal bossing is seen in congenital hemolytic anemias such as thalassemia and sickle cell anemia due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, but not typically in MAHA.

 

Option D. Goitre: Goitre is related to thyroid disorders and is not associated with hemolytic anemia or mechanical heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with anemia, hemoglobinuria, increased LDH, and schistocytes on a peripheral smear, the presence of a mechanical second heart sound can support the diagnosis of angiopathic hemolytic anemia due to mechanical heart valves. The mechanical destruction of red blood cells leads to intravascular hemolysis, characteristic laboratory findings, and specific physical examination findings related to the heart valve.

questions.text:
Which of the statements below accurately pertain to amyloidosis? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. It is an extracellular protein.
  2. It is called amyloid because of starch like deposition.
  3. Beta-pleated sheets are seen on X-ray crystallography
  4. AL is a secondary type of amyloidosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3  

 

Amyloidosis is a group of diseases characterized by the deposition of abnormal, misfolded proteins in tissues. These proteins form beta-pleated sheets, which can be detected using X-ray crystallography.

 

1. Extracellular protein: Amyloid is an extracellular deposit of abnormal proteins that form non-branching fibrils. These fibrils are composed primarily of misfolded protein subunits that aggregate into an insoluble form.

 

2. Amyloid and starch like deposition: The term "amyloid" is derived from the word "amylum," meaning starch. The term was historically used because amyloid deposits initially stained with iodine, similar to starch. However, amyloid is NOT starch but has similar staining characteristics. (starch-like)

 

3. Beta-pleated sheets: A defining feature of amyloid is the presence of beta-pleated sheet structures in the fibrils. This secondary structure can be identified through techniques such as X-ray crystallography and is crucial for the amyloid's characteristic properties.

 

Other Option:

 

4. AL (Amyloid Light chain): Is associated with primary amyloidosis, not secondary. Secondary amyloidosis is most often associated with AA (Amyloid A) protein, derived from the acute-phase reactant serum amyloid A.

 

Additional Information

 

A. Generalized/Systemic Amyloidosis

 

 

B. Localised Amyloidosis

 

 

C. Hereditary Amyloidosis

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient presented with a rectal mass 2.5 cm by 3 cm. On biopsy it had the presence of colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells.  Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartoma

 

The clinical history of a rectal mass on biopsy having the colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is suggestive of a juvenile polyp. This polyp is an example of a hamartomatous polyp.     

 

Hamartoma:

 

  • Definition: A hamartoma is a benign, focal malformation that resembles a neoplasm but grows at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. It is composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue elements that are normally found at that site.
  • Juvenile Polyp: A type of hamartomatous polyp commonly found in children. It is characterized by the presence of dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells, as described in the biopsy findings.
  • Clinical Presentation: Typically presents as a solitary rectal polyp in young children, often causing painless rectal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choristoma: A benign growth of normal tissue in an abnormal location, not consistent with the described biopsy findings.

 

Option C. Adenoma: A benign neoplasm of glandular tissue, typically presenting with dysplastic changes, not the dilated glands with mucin and inflammatory cells.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: A malignant tumor of glandular origin, which would show invasive growth and cellular atypia, not consistent with the benign nature of the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A rectal mass in a young child with biopsy findings of colonic mucosa and multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is indicative of a juvenile polyp, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100hz tuning fork)?(INICET 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 20 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency - 1/contraction period

 

Where the contraction period is the time taken from the end of latent period (Beginning of the upstroke) to maximum force of contraction(maximum height of upstroke i.e beginning of the downstroke).

 

In the given diagram, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork. Which means, the tracer (Waves shown below the main graph) recorded 100 waves per second, below the twitch graph.

 

Therefore, the duration of each wave in time tracer = 0.01 seconds.

 

The formula used to calculate the tetanizing frequency is:

 

Tetanizing frequency = 1 / contraction period

 

Substituting the values obtained:

 

Tetanizing frequency = 1 / 0.05 sec = 20/sec

 

Therefore, the tetanizing frequency of the muscle is 20 per second.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum tetanizing frequency of a muscle is determined by the reciprocal of the contraction period.
